Ségou Region is an administrative region in Mali, situated in the centre of the country with an area of 64,821 km2 (around 5% of Mali). The region is bordered by Sikasso Region on the south, Tombouctou and Mopti on the east, Burkina Faso to the southeast and the Koulikoro Region to the west. In 2009 it had 2,336,255 inhabitants, making it the second most populous region of Mali. Its administrative capital is the town of Ségou.
Ségrie is a commune in the Sarthe department in the region of Pays-de-la-Loire in north-western France.
Ségrie-Fontaine is a commune in the Orne department in north-western France. On 1 January 2016, it was merged into the new commune of Athis-Val-de-Rouvre.[1]
Ségur is a commune in the Aveyron department in southern France. Its inhabitants are the Ségurois, Séguroises.
Ségur-les-Villas is a commune in the Cantal department in south-central France.
Ségur is a station on line 10 of the Paris Metro on the border of the 7th and 15th arrondissements.

The river begins at Santiago Pontones (province of Jaén), passes Calasparra, Cieza, Blanca, Murcia, Murcia, Beniaján, Orihuela, Rojales and ends in the Mediterranean Sea near Guardamar del Segura in the province of Alicante. Some of its tributaries are the Mundo (which starts near Riópar), the Alhárabe (which starts in Moratalla), the Mula and the Guadalentín.
Séguédin is a town in the Nanoro Department of Boulkiemdé Province in central western Burkina Faso. It has a population of 3,615.[1]
Séguéla is a town in western Ivory Coast. It is the seat of both the Woroba District and the Worodougou Region. It is also a commune and the seat of and a sub-prefecture of Séguéla Department.
Seguenega is a department or commune of Yatenga Province in northern Burkina Faso. Its capital lies at the town of Ouahigouya.[1]

Sékou is a town and arrondissement in the Atlantique Department of southern Benin. It is an administrative division under the jurisdiction of the commune of Allada. According to the population census conducted by the Institut National de la Statistique Benin on February 15, 2002, the arrondissement had a total population of 16,124.[1]

Sélange (Séilen in Luxemburgisch, Selingen in German language) is a village in Luxembourg Province, in southern Belgium. It was previously a municipality, but is now part of Messancy. Nearby is the source of the River Eisch.

Sélestat (French: [selɛsta]; Alsatian: Schlettstàdt; German: Schlettstadt) is a commune in the north-east region of France. An administrative division (sous-préfecture) of the Bas-Rhin department, the town lies on the Ill river, 17 kilometres (11 mi) from the Rhine and the German border. Sélestat is located between the largest communes of Alsace, Strasbourg and Mulhouse.
Séligney is a commune in the Jura department and Bourgogne-Franche-Comté region of eastern France.

The Sélingué Dam is an embankment dam with a gravity section located in the Sikasso Region, on the Sankarani River, one of the affluents of the Niger River. It is an important center of energy production in Mali surpassed only by the Manantali Dam on the Bafing River.
Sémalens is a commune in the Tarn department in southern France.
Sémelay is a commune in the Nièvre department in central France. The town of Sémelay belongs to the canton of Luzy and the district of Château-Chinon(Ville).[2]
Sémeries is a commune in the Nord department in northern France.
The Séminaire des Pères Maristes (SPM) is a private, coeducational high school in Quebec City, Quebec, Canada. It is situated on the heights of Sillery and run by a team of Marist Fathers and laymen.
Sénaillac-Latronquière is a commune in the Lot department in south-western France.
Sénaillac-Lauzès is a commune in the Lot department in south-western France.
Sénanque Abbey (Occitan: abadiá de Senhanca, French: Abbaye Notre-Dame de Sénanque) is a Cistercian abbey near the village of Gordes in the département of the Vaucluse in Provence, France.

Shiv Sena (IAST: Śiva Sēnā) (translation; Army of Shivaji), is a Marathi regional and Hindu nationalist political organisation in India founded on 19 June 1966 by political cartoonist Bal Thackeray.[14] The party originally emerged from a movement in Bombay (present-day Mumbai) demanding preferential treatment for Maharashtrians over migrants to the city. It is currently headed by Thackeray's son, Uddhav Thackeray. Members of Shiv Sena are referred to as Shivsainiks.
Sénergues (Languedocien: Senèrgas) is a commune in the Aveyron department in southern France.
Sénestis is a commune in the Lot-et-Garonne department in south-western France.
Séneujols is a commune in the Haute-Loire department in south-central France.
Sénezergues is a commune in the Cantal department in south-central France.
Séniergues is a commune in the Lot department in south-western France.
Séno is one of the 45 provinces of Burkina Faso, located in its Sahel Region. The name of the province comes from the Fulfulde seeno, for "sandy plain."
Sénoville is a commune in the Manche department in Normandy in north-western France.
Sényő is a village in Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg county, in the Northern Great Plain region of eastern Hungary.
Séné (Breton: Sine) is a commune in the Morbihan department of Brittany in north-western France.
Sénéchas is a commune in the Gard department in southern France.
Sépeaux is a former commune in the Yonne department in Bourgogne-Franche-Comté in north-central France. On 1 January 2016, it was merged into the new commune of Sépeaux-Saint-Romain.[2]

Sépeaux-Saint-Romain is a commune in the Yonne department of central France. The municipality was established on 1 January 2016 by merger of the former communes of Sépeaux and Saint-Romain-le-Preux.[1]
Séranvillers-Forenville is a commune in the Nord department in northern France.
Séreilhac (Occitan: Cerelhac) is a commune in the Haute-Vienne department in the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region in west-central France.
Sérent (Breton: Serent) is a commune in the Morbihan department of Brittany in north-western France.
Sériers (Auvergnat: Cerièrs) is a former commune in the Cantal department in south-central France. On 1 January 2017, it was merged into the new commune Neuvéglise-sur-Truyère.[1]
Sérifontaine is a commune in the Oise department in northern France.
Sérignac is a commune in the Lot department in south-western France.
Sérignac is a commune in the Tarn-et-Garonne department in the Occitanie region in southern France.
Sérignac-Péboudou is a commune in the Lot-et-Garonne department in south-western France.
Sérignac-sur-Garonne is a commune in the Lot-et-Garonne department in south-western France.
Sérignan is a commune in the Hérault department in the Occitanie region in southern France.
Sérigny is a former commune in the Orne department in north-western France. On 1 January 2017, it was merged into the new commune Belforêt-en-Perche.[1]
Sérigny is a commune in the Vienne department in the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region in western France.
Sérigné is a commune in the Vendée department in the Pays de la Loire region in western France. It is located 48km away from La Roche-sur-Yon, the capital city of Vendée[2]
La Bastide-de-Sérou is a commune in the Ariège department in the Occitanie region of south-western France.[2]
Séry-Magneval is a commune in the Oise department in northern France.
Séry-lès-Mézières is a commune in the Aisne department in Hauts-de-France in northern France.
Sérédou is a town and sub-prefecture in the Macenta Prefecture in the Nzérékoré Region of south-eastern Guinea.[1]
